intro: Quercus oxyrhyncha, commonly known as the Mexican white oak, is a deciduous tree native to Mexico. It belongs to the Fagaceae family and is characterized by its broad, lobed leaves that turn yellow in autumn. The tree produces small, cup-shaped acorns that are an important food source for various wildlife species. Quercus oxyrhyncha typically grows in dry to moist forests and is adapted to a range of soil types. Its ecological significance lies in its role as a habitat provider and its contribution to local biodiversity.
